fileheader.author: Aeromatic v 3.3.15
fileheader.documentation:
Manufacturer: Handley Page Model: Victor B.2 Variant: Victor B.Mk 2R (Retrofit)
General Characteristics ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Crew: 5 (pilot, co-pilot, AEO, Navigator Radar, Navigator Plotter) Length (overall): 114 ft 11 in (35.03 m) Length (fuselage): 102 ft 5 in Wingspan (b): 119.7 ft (36.48 m) Height: 28 ft 1.5 in (8.57 m) Empty weight: 90,996 lb (41,275 kg) Max takeoff weight: 216,009 lb (97,980 kg) 223,000 lb (101,153 kg) with two de Havilland Spectre RATO units each rated at 8,000 lb st (35.59 kN) Landing weight: 135,000 lb - 185,000 lb (emergency) Diameter (bomb bay): 10 ft Track: 30 ft 2 in Powerplant: 4 x Conway RCo.17
Airfoil: 16% Modified RAE Airfoil; Tip: 6% Modified RAE Airfoil ~~~~~~~
Wing area (S): 2,597 sq ft (241.3 sq m) Standard mean chord (SMC), feet: 21.65 ft Aerodynamic mean chord, feet: 34.888 Wing root chord, feet (Cr): 40.83 Tip chord, feet (Ct): 9.89 Aspect ratio (AR): 5.545 Taper ratio (lambda): 0.2422 Thickness chord ratio (root): 14.40 Thickness chord ratio (tip): 8.00 Sweepback angles 50% chord, degrees: 33.0° Section A 41.4° Section B 35.8° Section C 28.2° Section D Sweepback of the leading edge, degrees (Omega_LE): Sweepback of the quarter chord, degrees (Omega_1_4): Wing dihedral angle, degrees: 4.6° at Section A 1.6° at Section C 0.9° at Section D Wing incidence angle, degrees: 4.275° at Section A 2.017° at Section C -1.229° at Section D Tail Span: (Mark 1) 32 ft 8 in Tail Area: (Mark 1) 263.6 sq ft Airbrakes: (Mark 1) 29.5 sq ft Tail Sweep: (Mark 1) 56.73°
Performance ~~~~~~~~~~~
Maximum Speed: 645 mph / 555 kt (1,038 km/h) at 40,000-50,000 ft. (Mach 0.98) Cruise speed: 560-620 m.p.h. at 35,000-45,000 ft. Range: 4,600 miles (7,400 km) Service ceiling: 55,000 ft (16,764 m) Range: 4,000 nm (4,606 miles; 7,412 km) with inflight refuelling 2,000 km (2,303 miles; 3,706 km) on a hi-hi-hi mission 1,500 nm (1,727 miles; 2,780 km) on a hi-lo-hi mission
Speeds ~~~~~~ * Stall, VS1: 120 knots * Rotation speed, VR: 150 knots * Undercarriage lowering: 235 knots * Approach speed: 160 knots * Landing speed: 135 knots
ENGINES: Rolls-Royce Conway RB.80 RCo.17 Mk.201 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
General characteristics Type: Turbofan Length: 136.0 in Diameter: 42 in (1,100 mm) Dry weight: 4,544 lb (2,061 kg)
Components Compressor: dual axial flow; 7-stage LP, 9-stage HP Combustors: cannular steel with 10 Nimonic flames tubes Turbine: axial flow; 1-stage HP (Nimonic air-cooled blades), 2-stage LP Oil system: Wet sump type
Performance Maximum thrust: 20,600 (91.633 KN) @ 9980 rpm (100%) Overall pressure ratio: 14.1:1 Bypass ratio: 0.30:1 Air mass flow: 280 lb (127 kg) per sec Specific fuel consumption: 0.725 @ sea level rating; typical cruise sfc=0.874 Thrust-to-weight ratio: 3.85
Electrical and Hydraulic Systems ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Main system: 4 x 208 V AC alternators generating 73 KVA
Engine start: Air-starters supplied from a Palouste compressor on the ground Standby: Ram air turbine (RAT) driving a 17 kVA alternator at altitudes above 20,000 ft (6,100 m) Airborne auxiliary power plant (AAPP), a Turbomeca Artouste auxiliary power Secondary: Transformer-rectifier units (TRUs) for 24 V DC and rotary frequency converters producing 112 V DC single phase supplies
Fuel ~~~~ Type: JP-1, also known as AVTUR, or AVTAG or AVCAT Capacity: 84,456 lbs in total in 22 tanks: Fuselage - 34,026 lbs in 8 tanks Wings - 17,316 lbs in 6 tanks for each wing Bombbay - 15,800 in two tanks
fileheader.note: References: 1. https://cmchant.com/bae-handley-page-victor-classic-british-bomber/ 2. https://www.militaryfactory.com/aircraft/detail.php?aircraft_id=241 3. Aeronautical Research Council Current Papers No. 1283, 1974 4. Aeronautical Research Council Reports and Memoranda No. 3455, 1967

========================== Aircraft Stability Notes ==========================
All aerodynamic forces and moments in JSBSim are calculated relative to the Aerodynamic Reference Point (AeroRP). The location of this point generally depends on how the coefficients were derived and is most often the quarter chord of the wing. If this location is not exactly equal to the center of gravity (CoG) then moments, or twisting forces, will be created. Conventional aircraft need AeroRP to be aft of the CoG for stability.
Static margin the distance between the aerodynamic center of the aircraft and its center of gravity. Static margin determines the degree of static stability of the aircraft. Decreasing static margin results in a decrease in the stability of the aircraft.
If the center of gravity is forward of the the aerodynamic center, then the plane has static stability. Static instability results if the center of gravity is aft of the aerodynamic center. As the center of gravity moves aft (and static margin decreases), less elevator deflection is required to maneuver. If the static is large (the CoG is too far forward), then pitch control will be very weak and excessive elevator deflections will be needed to maneuver the plane.
All aerodynamic forces and moments in JSBSim are calculated relative to the Aerodynamic Reference Point (AeroRP). The location of this point generally depends on how the coefficients were derived and is most often the quarter chord of the wing. If this location is not exactly equal to the center of gravity (CoG) then moments, or twisting forces, will be created. Conventional aircraft need AeroRP to be aft of the CoG for stability.
